alt-summary-body.p: Jefferies Group, whose quarterly earnings rose 55% amid strength in its investment-banking and equities-trading units, is avoiding the headwinds that are slowing bigger Wall Street banks.

headline.main-hed: Jefferies Group profit rises 55% on investment banking growth $JEF
Jefferies Benefits From Not Being Big

summary-body.p: Jefferies Group, whose profit rose 55% in the latest quarter, is avoiding the headwinds that are slowing bigger Wall Street banks.

list-item.link: Heard on the Street: Jefferies Doesn't Map Wall Street's Territory

headline.main-hed: Jefferies Benefits From Not Being Big
headline.deck: Growth in Investment Banking, Trading Helps Profit Rise 55%

article-body.byline: By Saabira Chaudhuri and Gillian Tan
article-body.p: Jefferies Group LLC is avoiding the headwinds that are slowing bigger Wall Street banks.

The firm owned by financial holding company Leucadia National Corp. reported a 55% surge in fiscal second-quarter earnings, driven by gains in underwriting of stocks and bonds and in revenue from providing advice on mergers. Fixed-income trading revenue fell 5%, a much smaller decline than rivals have warned investors to brace for.

The New York firm's results often are pored over for clues about how larger banks will perform. They show Jefferies riding the boom in mergers and acquisitions while picking up market share in trading and deal financing, sometimes unencumbered by new capital and lending rules hampering competitors.

The biggest U.S. banks aren't scheduled to report second-quarter earnings until next month. But in May, J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. and Citigroup Inc. warned that trading revenue for the quarter ending June 30 would be down sharply from a year earlier due to continued weakness in fixed-income, currencies and commodities trading.

list-item.link: Heard on the Street: Jefferies Doesn't Map Wall Street's Territory

article-body.p: For the period ended May 31, Jefferies reported profit rose to $61.3 million, from $39.5 million a year earlier. Revenue gained 9.8%. Leucadia shares added 37 cents, or 1.4%, to $26.53.

Jefferies's investment-banking net revenue jumped 19% to $331.1 million, bringing its advisory and underwriting business a step closer to being on the same level as its more established trading franchise. Capital-markets revenue, which includes businesses advising on stock and bond deals, climbed 23% to $230.7 million. Revenue from merger advice rose 12% to $100.4 million.

Compared with larger peers, Jefferies's traders deal mainly in plain-vanilla securities rather than over-the-counter derivatives or less easily traded securities, which has helped its fixed-income trading business hold up better than rivals'. The investment bank also benefits as bigger banks are forced to retool their approach to fixed income amid stricter balance-sheet requirements.

Trading revenue increased 6.5% to $394.9 million, as Jefferies offset a 5% drop in revenue from its fixed-income unit with a 25% jump in its smaller equities-trading business. However, stripping out the impact of certain equity block trades, equities-trading revenue was down 5%.

Chief Executive Richard Handler said Jefferies is continuing to add staff to its investment-banking team. The bank has raised its overall head count by 63% since 2008, at a time when many other banks are cutting staff in a bid to rein in expenses.
Goldman Sachs analyst Alexander Blostein said Jefferies investment-banking results are indicative of a strong environment for M&A and equity capital markets.

Jefferies has been catching up to its more prestigious investment-banking peers since the financial crisis. In the quarter ended Feb. 28, its investment-banking revenue of $414 million was about 23% of the first-quarter revenue of Goldman Sachs Group Inc.'s investment-bank division and more than 30% of the comparable revenue at Morgan Stanley. In late 2009, Jefferies's investment-banking revenue tallied only about 10% to 15% of the amount generated by the two larger peers.

Jefferies, like its rivals, also has enjoyed the fruits of a rebound in initial public offerings, particularly by biotechnology companies. It has been the top underwriter on seven of those deals so far in 2014, up from three last year, according to IPO data provider Syndicate Pro LLC.

Jefferies's results indicate that big banks could possibly report strong investment-banking results in the second quarter, helping to partly offset what is expected to be another weak quarter in fixed-income trading.

While Jefferies's performance in debt capital markets has proved more mixed than other parts of investment banking in the second quarter, Goldman's Mr. Blostein notes that Jefferies's debt capital-markets business is heavily tilted toward credit, which has held up better than other areas of the debt market.

Jefferies also has risen in the ranks among providers of financing for U.S. leveraged buyouts. In 2013, Jefferies for the first time cracked the top 10 in the ranking of underwriters of LBO loans. It is still holding steady in the 10th spot, according to Dealogic. Jefferies ranked 13th in 2012 and held the 12th spot in 2011 and 2010. In 2009, it wasn't even among the top 20 providers of such loans.

The firm's steady rise up the league tables comes as traditional lenders come under pressure from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve to avoid financing buyout deals in most industries that would put debt on a company of more than six times its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Jefferies isn't subject to the same regulatory regime as bank-holding companies, which are being discouraged from lending to deals with stretched payment timelines or that don't contain lender protections known as covenants.

Jefferies has told private-equity firms looking for deal financing that it can be more aggressive than banks subject to recent guidance designed to deter banks from funding deals that regulators feel are too laden with debt, according to people familiar with the firm's pitches.

Jefferies is leading an $825 million debt-package financing KKR & Co.-backed Brickman Group Ltd.'s proposed acquisition of landscaping company ValleyCrest from Michael Dell's MSD Capital. Five regulated banks that backed KKR's original buyout of Brickman passed on the ValleyCrest deal amid concerns that financing it would violate the lending guidance.
Write to Saabira Chaudhuri at saabira.chaudhuri@wsj.com and Gillian Tan at gillian.tan@wsj.com
